headline: Montgomery County Commissioner Val Arkoosh suspends U.S. Senate run
author: Rachel Ravina
sentences:
“Because there is so much work that needs to be done to lift up Pennsylvania families.”
“Since launching this campaign, we have logged a lot of miles, meeting with workers, families and small business owners, child care providers, families impacted by fracking and this climate crisis and women who make clear the need to protect abortion access,” Arkoosh went on to say.

Each day on the labor and delivery floor, pregnant moms manage diabetes without access to a grocery store in their neighborhood; dads who had to miss the birth of a child for fear they’d lose their job; people denied insurance for a preexisting condition.”
“There was just nothing I could do as a doctor to address those problems.” she continued.

“I said from the beginning, we would help build a campaign about Pennsylvanians and for Pennsylvanians, and I will keep fighting for you each and every day.”
A statement detailing news of Arkoosh’s campaign suspension came about 10 months after she initially announced her intentions to run for higher office.

“That’s why I became a physician advocate for the Affordable Care Act, fighting for those patients outside the exam room and that fight has continued each day since.”
Arkoosh first entered the political arena in 2015.
“It’s become clear to me that the best way I can ensure that happens is to suspend my campaign today, and commit to doing whatever I can to help ensure we flip this seat in November,” Arkoosh said.
Her decision to drop out of the U.S. Senate race came after she trailed the pack in last weekend’s endorsement vote at the Democratic State Committee, according to The Associated Press.
Arkoosh conducted her residency program in anesthesiology “with a special focus on obstetrics” at Jefferson Medical College, according to her profile on the Montgomery County website.

“For them, we cannot let anything stand in the way of a Democrat being elected to the United States Senate.”
Arkoosh concluded her recorded remarks with gratitude to her supporters.
NORRISTOWN — Montgomery County Commissioners’ Chairwoman Val Arkoosh has dropped out of Pennsylvania’s U.S. Senate race, she said Friday in a video message.
Arkoosh, a Northwestern University graduate, earned an undergraduate degree in economics, according to a profile on the Montgomery County website.
She then obtained additional degrees from the University of Nebraska College of Medicine and the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health.
Arkoosh was elected that same year to serve a four-year term and was reelected in 2019, according to a profile on the Montgomery County website.
The state’s third-most populous county has 856,553 residents as of April 1, 2020, according to population estimates from the U.S. Census Bureau.
Arkoosh, 61, of Springfield Township, had been vying for the retiring Republican U.S. Sen. Pat Toomey’s seat representing the commonwealth.
She went on to spend more than two decades in the medical field and has also held leadership roles in the medical and nonprofit sectors.
“It’s why I became the chair of the commonwealth’s third-largest county, and it’s in large part why I got into this race,” Arkoosh said.
“My name may not be on the ballot, but make no mistake, I will still be fighting every day to help win this election.
She was chosen to fill a seat on the Montgomery County Board of Commissioners vacated by Leslie Richards.
“Each step I’ve taken in my life has been inspired by the people I’ve met along the way,” Arkoosh said.
The Montgomery County Democrat first announced her campaign in a press release back in April 2021.
There’s too much at stake,” Arkoosh said in a video message posted Friday morning to YouTube.
None of the candidates received enough votes for the party’s endorsement at the gathering.
“I want to thank all the supporters who got behind our campaign.
She also trailed two other Democratic candidates, Lt. Gov.
John Fetterman and Congressman Conor Lamb, in fundraising.
The outgoing senator’s term expires at the end of 2022.
Arkoosh ran unsuccessfully for Congress in 2014.
“As a physician, it was the patients I saw.
It means the world to me,” she said.
“I’ll see you soon.”
